question: Which is better: Real fruit juice or Tropicana?
answer: Both Real and Tropicana are packaged fruit juices with similar sugar content (around 10-12g per 100ml). Neither is as healthy as fresh juice, but both score similarly (45-55/100). Scan both with NutriGo to compare! Look for '100% juice' variants with no added sugar. Better choice: Fresh whole fruits with natural fiber intact!

question: Haldiram's namkeen or Bikano - which is healthier?
answer: Both Haldiram's and Bikano offer similar namkeen products with comparable health concerns - high sodium (600-900mg), high calories, and fried preparation. Specific scores vary by product. Scan both brands with NutriGo and compare sodium, fat content, and ingredients. Baked variants score better. Look for options with lower sodium and no trans fats!

question: Which instant noodles are least unhealthy?
answer: No instant noodles are truly healthy, but better options include: whole wheat variants (Maggi atta noodles), lower sodium options, and those without MSG. Most score 30-40/100. Scan with NutriGo and compare! Look for less than 800mg sodium, no MSG, and whole grain. Better alternative: whole wheat pasta with vegetables - much healthier!

question: Patanjali products vs regular brands - are they healthier?
answer: Patanjali products aren't automatically healthier! While some use natural ingredients, others have similar sugar/sodium levels as regular brands. Scan both Patanjali and competitors with NutriGo to compare actual nutrition, not marketing claims. Check health scores, ingredients, and nutritional content. Don't assume 'natural' means healthy!

question: Which packaged cookies are healthiest?
answer: Healthier packaged cookies typically include: digestive biscuits (McVitie's, Sunfeast), oat cookies, multigrain variants, and those with less than 10g sugar per serving. Scan options with NutriGo! Look for scores above 55, whole grain flour, lower sugar, and minimal additives. Dark chocolate digestive biscuits score better than cream-filled varieties!

question: Kurkure vs Cheetos - which is better?
answer: Both Kurkure and Cheetos are ultra-processed corn puff snacks with high sodium (400-500mg), artificial flavors, and low nutritional value. Both typically score 25-35/100. Scan with NutriGo to compare! Neither is healthy. Better alternatives: roasted makhana, baked chips, or air-popped popcorn for crunchy snacking without guilt!

question: Which packaged atta (flour) is best?
answer: Look for 100% whole wheat atta with no additives or preservatives. Aashirvaad, Pillsbury, and Fortune whole wheat variants score well (70-80/100). Scan with NutriGo! Check for: 100% whole wheat, no maida, high fiber content, and chakki atta if possible. Avoid refined flour blends. Local chakki-ground atta is often best!

question: Amul butter vs margarine - which is healthier?
answer: Amul butter is real dairy with saturated fat but no trans fats (score: 50-60/100). Margarine often contains trans fats and artificial ingredients (score: 30-45/100). Scan both with NutriGo! If choosing between them, butter is more natural. But use both sparingly. Best option: use in moderation or try olive oil spreads!

question: Which packaged soup is healthiest?
answer: Healthier packaged soups have: less than 500mg sodium per serving, real vegetables, no MSG, and minimal preservatives. Knorr, Maggi, and Ching's soups vary widely - scan each with NutriGo! Homemade soup is always better. If buying packaged, choose options with simple ingredients, lower sodium, and add fresh vegetables!

question: Frooti vs Maaza vs Slice - which is better?
answer: All three (Frooti, Maaza, Slice) are similar - high sugar fruit drinks (around 10-12g per 100ml) with limited real fruit content. All score low (25-35/100) due to high sugar and minimal nutrition. Scan all three with NutriGo! None is significantly better. Better choice: Fresh fruit juice at home or whole fruits!

question: Which packaged cheese is healthiest?
answer: Healthier cheese options include: Amul processed cheese (in moderation), Britannia cheese slices, or natural cheese variants. Look for lower sodium (under 400mg per 30g), real cheese ingredients, and higher protein. Scan with NutriGo! Avoid cheese spreads with high additives. Best: Fresh paneer or natural mozzarella/cheddar in moderation!

question: Bisleri vs Kinley water - any difference?
answer: Both Bisleri and Kinley are purified packaged water with similar quality standards and mineral content. Health-wise, both are equally safe (score: 100/100 for plain water!). Choose based on availability and price. The important thing is staying hydrated with clean water. Invest in a good home water purifier to save money!

question: Which packaged tea is healthiest?
answer: Healthiest packaged teas include: green tea (Organic India, Twinings), herbal teas without sugar, black tea without additives, and organic varieties. Avoid premix teas with sugar and milk powder. Scan with NutriGo! Look for pure tea leaves, no added sugar, organic certification, and antioxidant-rich varieties like green or white tea!

question: MTR vs Gits ready-to-eat meals - which is better?
answer: Both MTR and Gits offer ready-to-eat Indian meals with similar convenience but high sodium (800-1200mg). Scan specific products with NutriGo to compare! Check for sodium content, preservatives, and calories. Both score 40-55/100. Better option: Home-cooked meals frozen in batches. If needed, choose lower sodium variants!

question: Which packaged dal is best to buy?
answer: When buying packaged dal, look for: clean, unbroken grains, no additives, proper sealing, and trusted brands like Tata Sampann, India Gate, or Fortune. All pure dals score high (85-95/100) as they're minimally processed. Scan with NutriGo! Avoid pre-cooked dal packets with high sodium. Buy raw dal for maximum nutrition!

question: Limca vs Sprite vs 7Up - which soda is least bad?
answer: All three (Limca, Sprite, 7Up) are sugar-sweetened sodas with similar profiles - high sugar (around 39g per 330ml), zero nutrition, artificial flavors. All score very low (20-30/100). Scan with NutriGo to see warnings! None is less bad. Better alternatives: Fresh lime soda with less sugar, sparkling water, or plain water!

question: Which packaged pickle brand is healthiest?
answer: Healthier pickles have: lower sodium (under 600mg per serving), minimal oil, no artificial colors, and traditional fermentation. Brands like Priya, Mother's Recipe, and Patanjali vary by product. Scan with NutriGo! Look for homestyle pickles with simple ingredients. Remember, all pickles are high in sodium - use sparingly!

question: Kellogg's vs Bagrry's cereals - which is better?
answer: Bagrry's generally scores better (65-75/100) with less sugar and more whole grains compared to Kellogg's sugary cereals (40-60/100). But it varies by product - scan both with NutriGo! Look for: less than 10g sugar per serving, whole grains first ingredient, at least 5g fiber. Best option: Plain oats with fresh fruits!

question: Which packaged ghee is best?
answer: Quality packaged ghee brands include Amul, Mother Dairy, Patanjali, and Nandini - all score similarly (55-65/100) as ghee is pure saturated fat. Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 100% cow or buffalo milk, A2 ghee if preferred, no additives. All pure ghee is similar nutritionally. Use in moderation for cooking!

question: Thumbs Up vs Thums Up Zero - which is better?
answer: Regular Thums Up is high in sugar (about 39g per 330ml, score: 20-25/100). Thums Up Zero has zero calories but artificial sweeteners (score: 35-40/100). Scan both with NutriGo! Neither is healthy - one has excessive sugar, other has artificial sweeteners. Better choice: Plain water, nimbu pani, or unsweetened iced tea!

question: Which packaged peanut butter is healthiest?
answer: Healthiest peanut butters have: 100% peanuts (or 95%+ with salt), no added sugar, no hydrogenated oils, and natural separation. Brands like MyFitness, Pintola, and Alpino natural variants score best (75-85/100). Scan with NutriGo! Avoid brands with palm oil, sugar, and additives. Check ingredients - fewer is better!

question: Cadbury vs Amul chocolate - which is better?
answer: Both are milk chocolates with high sugar. Amul dark chocolate (70%+ cocoa) scores much better (75-80/100) than Cadbury Dairy Milk (40-45/100) due to lower sugar and antioxidants. Scan with NutriGo! For healthier chocolate, choose dark varieties with 70%+ cocoa and less added sugar. Dark chocolate wins!

question: Which packaged masala/spice brand is safest?
answer: Trusted spice brands include MDH, Everest, Tata Sampann, and Catch - all use quality control. Pure spices score high (90-95/100). Scan masala blends with NutriGo for added salt and fillers! Look for: no artificial colors, minimal salt, single-ingredient spices when possible. Always check for adulterants. Buy whole spices when you can!

question: Coca-Cola Zero vs regular Coke - is Zero better?
answer: Regular Coke has massive sugar (39g per 330ml, score: 20/100). Coke Zero has zero calories but artificial sweeteners aspartame and acesulfame-K (score: 35/100). Scan both with NutriGo! Neither is truly healthy. Zero is marginally better for diabetics but artificial sweeteners have concerns. Best choice: Water or fresh beverages!

question: Which packaged rice brand is best?
answer: For white rice, brands like India Gate, Daawat, and Fortune offer quality basmati. Brown rice scores better health-wise (80-85/100 vs 60-65/100 for white). Scan with NutriGo! Look for: aged basmati for white rice, or choose brown/red rice for more fiber and nutrients. All pure rice is similar - choose by quality and type!

question: Parle-G vs Good Day biscuits - which is healthier?
answer: Parle-G (glucose biscuits) scores slightly better (45-50/100) than Good Day butter cookies (35-40/100) due to lower fat. But both are refined flour products with sugar. Scan both with NutriGo! Neither is particularly healthy. Better options: Digestive biscuits or oat cookies with whole grains and less sugar!

question: Which packaged paneer brand is best?
answer: Quality paneer brands include Amul, Mother Dairy, Govardhan, and Nandini - all score well (75-85/100) for fresh paneer. Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 100% cow milk, no preservatives, recent manufacturing date, and proper refrigeration. Fresh paneer from local dairy is often better than packaged. Check expiry dates!

question: Bournvita vs Horlicks - which is healthier?
answer: Both Bournvita and Horlicks are malted health drinks with high sugar (70-75% of calories from sugar!). Both score low (35-45/100) despite health claims. Scan with NutriGo for truth! Marketing says 'health drink' but they're basically sugar. Better option: Plain milk with banana, dates, or almonds for natural nutrition!

question: Which packaged frozen food is healthiest?
answer: Healthiest frozen options include: plain frozen vegetables (score: 85-95/100), frozen fruits, plain grilled chicken/fish, and minimal-ingredient items. Avoid breaded, fried, or heavily sauced frozen foods. Scan with NutriGo! Look for: simple ingredients, no added sauces, low sodium, and recognizable foods. Frozen vegetables retain nutrients well!

question: Red Bull vs Monster vs Sting - which energy drink is safest?
answer: All energy drinks (Red Bull, Monster, Sting) are concerning with high caffeine (80-150mg), massive sugar (27-39g), and artificial ingredients. All score very low (15-25/100). Scan with NutriGo for warnings! None is safe for regular consumption. Better energy: Green tea, black coffee, or banana with nuts!

question: Which packaged oil is healthiest?
answer: Healthiest packaged oils include: olive oil (extra virgin), rice bran oil, mustard oil, and groundnut oil for Indian cooking. Avoid refined and hydrogenated oils. Scan with NutriGo! Look for: cold-pressed when possible, single-source oils, no trans fats. Different oils for different purposes - olive for salads, mustard for cooking!

question: Sunfeast vs Britannia biscuits - which brand is better?
answer: Both Sunfeast and Britannia offer various biscuits with similar quality. Health scores depend on specific products - digestive biscuits (55-65/100) vs cream biscuits (35-45/100). Scan specific items with NutriGo! Compare sugar, fat, and ingredients. Both brands have healthier and unhealthier options. Choose based on nutrition, not brand!

question: Which packaged jam is healthiest?
answer: Healthier jams have: high fruit content (60%+), low/no added sugar, no artificial colors, and simple ingredients. Most regular jams score 30-40/100 due to high sugar. Scan with NutriGo! Look for 'no added sugar' or fruit-only spreads. Better option: Make fresh jam at home with fruits and minimal sugar!

question: Lays vs Bingo vs Kurkure - rank them healthiest to unhealthiest
answer: All three are unhealthy, but ranking: 1) Lays baked variants (35-40/100) - baked not fried, 2) Regular Lays chips (25-30/100) - fried potato, 3) Bingo chips (25-30/100) - similar to Lays, 4) Kurkure (20-25/100) - corn puffs with more additives. Scan all with NutriGo! All should be occasional treats, not regular snacks!

question: Which packaged coffee brand is best?
answer: Quality coffee brands include Nescafe, Bru, Tata Coffee, Blue Tokai, and local filter coffee. Pure coffee scores well (90-95/100). Avoid premix coffees with sugar and whitener. Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 100% coffee, no added sugar, arabica beans preferred. Instant coffee loses some nutrients but is convenient. Fresh ground is best!

question: Maggi sauce vs Kissan ketchup - which is better?
answer: Both are condiments with high sodium and sugar. Maggi sauce has more sodium (score: 30-35/100), Kissan ketchup has more sugar (score: 35-40/100). Scan both with NutriGo! Neither is particularly healthy. Use sparingly. Better alternatives: Homemade tomato sauce, mint chutney, or yogurt-based dips with real ingredients!

question: Which packaged pasta is healthiest?
answer: Healthiest pasta options include: whole wheat pasta (Del Monte, Borges), multigrain variants, or high-protein pasta. White pasta scores lower (55-60/100) vs whole wheat (70-75/100). Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 100% whole grain, at least 5g protein, high fiber. Pair with vegetables and healthy sauce for nutritious meal!

question: Paper Boat vs Raw Pressery drinks - which is healthier?
answer: Raw Pressery cold-pressed juices score higher (55-70/100) with no added sugar vs Paper Boat traditional drinks (40-50/100) with added sugars. Scan both with NutriGo! Raw Pressery preserves more nutrients through cold-pressing. But both lack fiber of whole fruits. Best option: Blend fresh fruits at home for maximum nutrition!

question: Which instant oats brand is best?
answer: Best instant oats brands include Saffola, Quaker, Kellogg's, and Bagrry's. Avoid flavored variants with added sugar. Plain instant oats score high (80-90/100). Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 100% oats, no added sugar or flavoring, high fiber content. Add your own fruits, nuts, and honey for healthy breakfast!

question: Nutella vs Hershey's chocolate spread - which is better?
answer: Both are sugar and palm oil bombs! Nutella (score: 25-30/100) and Hershey's spread (score: 25-30/100) have 55%+ sugar and unhealthy fats. Scan with NutriGo for shocking sugar content! Neither is healthy despite marketing. Better alternatives: Natural peanut butter, almond butter, or homemade date-nut spread!

question: Which packaged honey brand is pure?
answer: Pure honey brands include Dabur, Patanjali, Apis Himalaya, and local beekeepers. But adulteration is common! Pure raw honey scores well (75-80/100). Scan with NutriGo! Look for: 'raw' or 'organic' labels, single-source flowers, crystallization (good sign!), and lab-tested certification. Buy from trusted sources or local beekeepers!

question: Tropicana juice vs Minute Maid - any difference?
answer: Both Tropicana and Minute Maid (Coke product) are similar packaged juices with comparable sugar (10-12g per 100ml) and processing. Both score similarly (45-55/100). Scan both with NutriGo! Small differences in taste but similar nutrition. Neither replaces whole fruit. Choose based on preference, but limit intake. Fresh juice is always better!

question: Can I scan packaged products in regional Indian languages?
answer: Yes! NutriGo's AI can read nutrition labels in multiple Indian languages including Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, Malayalam, Bengali, Marathi, and Gujarati. Just take a photo of the product label in any language and our AI will extract the information. This makes NutriGo accessible across India for everyone!

question: What should I look for on packaged food labels?
answer: Key things to check on packaged food labels: 1) Ingredient list (shorter is better, recognize items), 2) Nutritional facts (calories, protein, fiber, sugar, sodium), 3) Serving size (often misleadingly small!), 4) Health claims vs actual nutrition, 5) Expiry dates, 6) Allergen warnings. NutriGo does all this analysis for you instantly - just scan!

question: Are 'sugar-free' packaged products actually healthy?
answer: Not always! 'Sugar-free' often means artificial sweeteners (aspartame, sucralose, saccharin) which have their own concerns. These products may still be processed and lack nutrients. Scan sugar-free products with NutriGo to check ingredients! Some score better than sugary versions, but natural low-sugar whole foods are always best. Check what replaces the sugar!

question: What does 'natural flavors' mean on packaged food?
answer: 'Natural flavors' is a vague term that can include 100+ FDA-approved ingredients derived from plant or animal sources but heavily processed. They're not always healthier than artificial flavors! NutriGo flags products with excessive flavorings. Look for foods where real ingredients provide flavor - like 'real strawberries' instead of 'natural strawberry flavor.'

question: Should I worry about E-numbers in packaged foods?
answer: E-numbers are food additives (preservatives, colors, stabilizers) coded in Europe but found globally. Some are harmless (E300 is vitamin C!), others concerning (E102 artificial color). NutriGo identifies and warns about harmful additives! Scan products to check. Generally avoid: E102, E110, E129 (colors), E250 (nitrites), E320 (BHA). Fewer E-numbers = better!

question: What's the difference between 'best before' and 'expiry date'?
answer: 'Best before' means quality/taste may decline after this date but product is still safe (for dry goods). 'Expiry date' or 'use by' means don't consume after this for safety (for perishables like dairy, meat). NutriGo can't scan dates, but always check labels! When in doubt, use your senses - smell, look, taste a tiny bit!

question: Are packaged foods with longer shelf life more unhealthy?
answer: Not automatically, but often yes! Long shelf life usually means: more preservatives, more processing, less moisture (nutrients concentrate in water), and fewer fresh ingredients. However, frozen vegetables and properly canned goods can be nutritious. Scan long shelf-life products with NutriGo to check preservatives and health scores! Fresh is usually better.

question: What does 'fortified' mean on packaged foods?
answer: Fortified means vitamins/minerals were added during processing that weren't naturally present. Common in cereals, flour, milk, and salt (iodine). Can be beneficial (preventing deficiencies) or marketing gimmick (fortifying junk food). Scan fortified products with NutriGo! While added nutrients help, getting vitamins from whole foods is always preferable. Don't choose junk food just because it's fortified!

question: Is 'multigrain' better than 'whole grain' on packaged foods?
answer: NO! 'Multigrain' just means multiple grains, which could be refined. 'Whole grain' means the entire grain kernel (bran, germ, endosperm) is intact - much more nutritious with fiber. Scan both with NutriGo! Look for '100% whole grain' or 'whole wheat' as first ingredient. Multigrain refined flour is still refined! Choose whole grain for maximum nutrition.

question: What does 'made with real fruit' mean?
answer: 'Made with real fruit' often means minimal fruit content - could be 2-5%! Companies use this for marketing. Check ingredients list - fruit should be near the top. Many products use 'fruit juice concentrate' which is basically sugar. Scan with NutriGo to check actual fruit content and sugar levels! Real fruit = whole fruit pieces, not concentrate.

question: Are packaged 'organic' foods always healthier?
answer: Organic means grown without synthetic pesticides/fertilizers but doesn't automatically mean healthier nutrition. Organic cookies are still cookies! Organic reduces chemical exposure but check overall nutrition. Scan organic products with NutriGo - some score high (organic dal: 90+), others low (organic candy: 30). Focus on whole foods first, organic second.

question: What's 'high fructose corn syrup' and why avoid it?
answer: High fructose corn syrup (HFCS) is a cheap sweetener made from corn, sweeter than regular sugar, and linked to obesity, diabetes, and fatty liver disease when consumed in excess. Found in sodas, packaged sweets, and processed foods. NutriGo warns about HFCS! Avoid products listing it in first 5 ingredients. Regular sugar isn't great either, but HFCS is worse!

question: Do I need to scan every packaged product I buy?
answer: Ideally scan new products or regular purchases to understand what you're eating! Once you've scanned a product, NutriGo saves it to history. You don't need to rescan the same item unless checking for reformulation. Scan when: trying new brands, comparing similar products, unsure about health claims, or shopping for family members with dietary restrictions. Knowledge is power!

question: Can NutriGo help me if I'm allergic to something?
answer: Absolutely! NutriGo's allergen detection specifically identifies common allergens (gluten, dairy, nuts, soy, eggs, fish, shellfish) in packaged products. Scan before buying to avoid triggers! While we're very accurate, always double-check labels yourself for severe allergies. Use NutriGo as a helpful tool, not replacement for careful reading when health is at stake.

question: Why do some healthy-looking products score low?
answer: Marketing tricks! Products labeled 'natural,' 'healthy,' or 'wholesome' may still have high sugar, sodium, unhealthy fats, or excessive processing. NutriGo looks beyond marketing at actual nutrition and ingredients. We've seen 'healthy' granola bars score 35/100 due to sugar! Always scan to get truth behind claims. Don't trust front-of-package marketing!

question: Can I suggest products to add to NutriGo's database?
answer: Yes! If a product isn't in our database, you can still scan it by taking a photo of the label - our AI will analyze it! We continuously expand our database based on user scans. The more people scan, the smarter NutriGo becomes. You're helping build a comprehensive Indian packaged food database. Thank you for contributing!

question: How often does NutriGo update product information?
answer: We regularly update our packaged food database with: new products, reformulated items, corrected nutritional info, and manufacturer updates. When companies reformulate, it takes time to update databases. If you notice outdated info, the photo scan feature will analyze current labels. Always check manufacturing dates - recent products have latest formulations!

question: Can schools use NutriGo for nutrition education?
answer: Absolutely! NutriGo is perfect for teaching kids about nutrition. Schools can use it to: educate about reading labels, compare snack options for canteens, teach healthy food choices, make nutrition interactive and fun, and help kids develop lifelong healthy habits. We'd love to support nutrition education programs! Contact us for school partnerships.

question: Does NutriGo work for international packaged products?
answer: Yes! While we focus on Indian brands, NutriGo can scan international packaged products too. The barcode scanner works globally, and photo analysis reads any language label. Health scores use universal nutritional principles. International products in Indian stores are included in our database. Wherever you shop for packaged foods, NutriGo helps you choose wisely!

question: What's your favorite feature of NutriGo?
answer: I love the instant health scoring! It takes complex nutrition and makes it simple - just scan and see 70+ means good, below 50 means reconsider. The brand comparison feature is awesome too - finally answer 'Coke or Pepsi?' with data! And warnings about hidden nasties save people from unhealthy choices. NutriGo makes nutrition accessible to everyone!
